Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story: I stared at the email notification blinking on my screen: “Team meeting at 10 AM—attendance expected.” It was just a routine catch-up, and I knew it would be recorded for anyone who couldn’t make it. Still, as a colleague, I felt the unspoken pressure to show up, to be present, to prove I was committed to the team. But my mind was elsewhere. My doctor’s words echoed in my head: “If you want to perform Hajj, this year may be your last chance to travel safely.” As a Muslim, the pilgrimage is a sacred duty, something I’ve dreamed of fulfilling my whole life. The dates overlapped. I felt torn—my team counted on me, but my faith called me to something greater, something urgent. My heart pounded with anxiety as I weighed the expectations of my colleagues against the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to complete my religious obligation. I sat at my desk, paralyzed, unable to decide which part of myself I would have to disappoint.
